[[File:World trade map.PNG|thumb|557x557px|A world map of countries by trading status, late 20th century, using the world system differentiation into core countries (blue), semi-periphery countries (purple) and periphery countries (red). Based on the list in Dunn, Kawana, Brewer (2000).]] {{International relations theory sidebar}} In [[world-systems theory]], the '''semi-periphery countries''' (sometimes referred to as just '''the semi-periphery''') are the [[industrialization|industrializing]], mostly [[capitalism|capitalist]] [[country|countries]] which are positioned between [[periphery countries|the periphery]] and [[core countries]]. Semi-periphery countries have organizational characteristics of both core countries and periphery countries and are often geographically located between core and peripheral regions as well as between two or more competing core regions.<ref name=chase/> Semi-periphery regions play a major role in mediating economic, political, and social activities that link core and peripheral areas.<ref name=chase>Chase-Dunn and Thomas D. Hall.''The Seedbed of Change''.Chapter 5 of C.</ref>
These regions allow for the possibility of innovative technology, reforms in social and organizational structure, and dominance over peripheral nations.<ref name=chase/> These changes can lead to a semi-periphery country being promoted to a core nation.<ref name="chase"/> Semi-periphery is, however, more than a description, as it also serves as a position within the world hierarchy in which social and economic change can be interpreted.<ref name=terlouw>Terlouw 1992 pg 136-145</ref>
World-systems theory describes the semi-periphery as a key structural element in the world economy.<ref name=waller>Wallerstein 1976, pp. 229-233</ref> The semi-periphery plays a vital role comparative to that of the role that Spain and Portugal played in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries as intermediate trading groups within the European colonial empire.<ref name=waller/>
Today, the semi-periphery is generally industrialized.<ref name=waller2>Wallerstein 1974 Vol.3, No.4., pp 461-483</ref> Semi-peripheral countries contribute to the manufacturing and exportation of a variety of goods.<ref name=waller/> They are marked by above average land mass, as exemplified by Argentina, China, India, Brazil, Mexico, Indonesia, and [[Iran]].<ref name=terlouw/> More land mass typically means an increased market size and share.<ref name=waller2/> Semi-peripheral nations are not all large though, as smaller countries such as [[Israel]], Poland, and Greece exist within the semi-periphery.<ref name=waller2/>
==Sociological theory== Semi-peripheral countries offer their citizens relatively diverse economic opportunities but also have extreme gaps between the rich and poor. World-system theorists originally used only two categories: [[periphery countries]] and [[core countries]]. A need for an in between category became quickly apparent,<ref name="Chirot">Chirot. 1977.</ref> leading to the establishment of the semi-periphery category for societies that have moved away from the periphery but have not become core. In other words, the category describes societies that remain dependent, and to some extent underdeveloped, despite having achieved significant levels of industrialization.<ref name="Chirot"/> Semi-peripheral countries are tied into dynamic world systems that focus on the reliance of poor nations upon the wealthy, a concept known as the [[dependency theory]].<ref>Tausch A.</ref> The term semi-periphery has been applied to countries that existed as early as in the thirteenth century.<ref name=abu>Janet Abu-Lughod 1989</ref> In theory, the creation of a semi-periphery category has added sociological and historical layers to previous developmental theories—yet it still has similar, inherently capitalist foundations.<ref name="waller" />
===Function=== [[File:China fuels 1983.jpg|thumb|250px|Energy and mineral resources]] The semi periphery is needed to stabilize the world system,<ref name=waller/> as it facilitates interaction and provides a connection between the low-income [[periphery countries|peripheral states]] and the high-income [[core countries|core states]] by adding another step in the world system hierarchy.<ref name=waller/> As the middle ground, semi-peripheral countries display characteristics of both the [[Core countries|core]] and the [[Periphery countries|periphery]].<ref name=waller2/> They also serve as a political buffer zone in that while they are exploited, they are also the exploiters.<ref name=waller/> These areas have either been core regions in the past or formerly-peripheral areas that have since advanced in the world economy.<ref name=waller2/>
Semi-peripheral nations are a necessary structural element in a world-trade system,<ref name=waller/> since such nations can serve to alleviate the political pressures that the core can exert upon the periphery and the political unrest that the periphery can direct back at the core.<ref name=waller/> On the other hand, the semi-periphery can find itself excluded from the region's politics, as it lies just outside the bounds of political arena of the core states.<ref name=waller/>
The semi-periphery exists because it needs to divide the economic power between the core and the periphery. Semi-periphery, referred to as the middle class by Wallerstein, is what makes the capitalist world function because it is much like the sociological [[structural functionalism]] theory, where norms, customs, traditions, and institutions act as "organs" that work toward the proper functioning of the "body" as a whole. Without these industrializing countries, change will never reach the periphery.<ref>Chirot, Daniel, and Thomas D. Hall. 1982. 8:81-106.</ref>
In terms of their contribution to industry and economy, the contemporary semi-peripheral states are semi-industrialized.<ref name=waller2/> Semi-peripheral countries are major exporters of minerals and agricultural goods. They are often focused in the manufacturing and exportation of industrial goods and commodities. While these advances separate the semi-periphery from the periphery, they lack the power and the economic dominance of core nations and still have a lot of un-managed poverty, placing them beneath the core.<ref name=terlouw/> Semi-peripheral countries are important contributors to the world economy because of the above reasons and because they tend to have above average land mass, meaning that they are host to an above average market.<ref name=terlouw/> A primary example is China, a country with not only a large area but with a booming population.<ref name=terlouw/>
==History and development==
===13th century=== [[File:Silkroutes.jpg|thumb|Ancient [[silk road]] [[trade routes]] across [[Eurasia]]]]This era of human history found the semi-periphery concentrated in the area stretching from the Middle East to China, including India and the [[Mongol Empire]].<ref name=abu/> This was the first time in history that the peripheries and semi-peripheries of the world became connected and involved in the trade of the world, both with cores and with each other.<ref name=abu/> Through a lucrative trade system, including heavy taxing of goods traveling through their borders, they were able to maintain a steady stream of wealth, becoming the driving forces of economic change throughout this time period.<ref name=abu/> In addition, a heavy emphasis on defense and border security, particularly among the [[Mongols]], allowed them to be fairly impenetrable [[trade]] obstacles.<ref name=abu/> [[Geography]] also played a role, as seen in India's development of an impressive [[maritime industry]]. Because of its position along a convenient route through the Indian Ocean, India established its role as a "hinge" between the [[East]] and [[West]].<ref name=abu/> Through their positions within the world trade system, semi-peripheries in the Middle East became crucially important in connecting the cities of Chinese and Indian cores with the fledgling cities of Europe, as well as serving as key points between other, more major core cities in the region, such as [[Baghdad]], [[Cairo]], and [[Aden]].<ref name=abu/>
===1300–1450=== [[File:Bubonic plague-en.svg|thumb|250px|The Black Death rapidly spread along the major European sea and land trade routes.]]
Following increases in population and commerce in Western Europe in the thirteenth century, the [[feudal system]] met severe economic difficulties in the fourteenth and early fifteenth centuries.<ref name=halsall>Halsall 1997, pp.14-19</ref> This decline in development was caused by a combination of the decline in agricultural production, the shrinking economy that had already hit its peak within the current feudal structure, and the devastating effects of the [[Black Plague]] epidemic.<ref name=waller/> The regression of Western Europe into the semi-periphery and periphery allowed for the rise of the trading powers of Italy, most notably [[Genoa]] and [[Venice]].<ref name=abu/> These Italian city-states took advantage of their established trade connections with the [[Mongol Empire]], the [[Far East]], the Middle East, and the other Mediterranean powers to maintain their growth despite the economic failures of their European trade partners.<ref name=abu/> Genoa and Venice had influence beyond their trade channels. Both were instrumental in the [[Crusades]] through their provisions of troops, transport vessels, and naval ships.<ref name=abu/> Genoa also assisted the [[Byzantine Empire]] when it helped recapture the capital, [[Constantinople]], in the late thirteenth century.<ref name=abu/> The Byzantine Empire took advantage of its strategic position along various trade routes and the decline of Western Europe to rise to [[Core countries|core]] status until its fall in 1453.<ref name=abu/>
During this time period, Genoa and Venice developed forms of [[laissez-faire]] government and institutions that are viewed as precursors to modern [[capitalism]].<ref name=abu/> Despite these advances in influence and entrepreneurship, Genoa and Venice suffered from the crippling effects of the Black Plague, as much of the rest of Europe had before them.<ref name=abu/> Venice was able to survive due to its connection with the Southern trade route, though her strength was much reduced by the middle of the fifteenth century.<ref name=abu/> Genoa never fully recovered from the [[Black Death]] and its defeat at the hands of Venice in the late fourteenth century.<ref name=abu/> The decline of Genoa and the shift in Venice's focus to the [[Red Sea]] trade route left the western Mediterranean and the Atlantic open to Portugal and Spain, who were already better positioned geographically to control Atlantic trade routes.<ref name=abu/>
===1450–1700=== [[File:Spanish Empire Anachronous 0.PNG|thumb|460px|The areas of the world that at one time were territories of the Spanish Empire.]]
In a push to ensure stable economic growth, Europe turned to a capitalistic economy in the fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries to replace the failed feudal system.<ref name=halsall/> Modern capitalism allowed for economies to extend beyond geographical and political boundaries, leading to the formation of the first worldwide economic system.<ref name=halsall/> At the base of this world system was an [[international division of labor]] that determined countries' relationships and placement within the categories of the world system: core, semi-periphery, periphery, and external.<ref name=halsall/> The core regions, most notably the countries of Northwestern Europe like England, France, and the [[Netherlands]], gained the most from the world economy.<ref name=halsall/> Their ascension from previous peripheral and semi-peripheral status to the core was driven by the development of strong central government and military power, the combination of which made possible control of international commerce and exploitation of colonial possessions.<ref name=halsall/>
At the other end of the spectrum was the periphery, marked by lack of central government, exportation of raw materials to the core, and exploitive labor practices.<ref name=halsall/> In this time period, especially toward the end of the 17th century, South America and parts of North America stood out as peripheral zones under the control and capitalistic exploitation of core countries in Europe.<ref name=waller2/> [[Slaves]] and indigenous workers in these regions developed [[raw materials]] for export to Europe, a distinctive characteristic of the new capitalism, as goods were no longer produced solely for internal consumption.<ref name=halsall/> The [[aristocracy]] of these regions controlled commerce and became wealthy through the new world economy, leading to their rise in power above the government.<ref name=halsall/> Even in periods of upheaval, local aristocrats were able to rely on core European powers to assist in keeping control over the economic system.<ref name=halsall/>
In between the core and periphery was the semi-periphery, which constituted both previous core regions that had declined, like Italy, Spain and Portugal, and peripheries that had improved their position, like southern Germany and southern France.<ref name=halsall/> Spain and Portugal had taken advantage of the opening to Atlantic control left by the decline of Italian powers like Genoa and Venice.<ref name=halsall/> Much like the core European powers, Spain and Portugal had strong navies and expansive colonial domains, which they exploited for their natural resources and cheap labor.<ref name=halsall/> Rather than using the increased wealth to develop strong domestic [[manufacturing]] sectors, as other Western European powers did, Spain and Portugal used imported gold and silver to obtain manufactured goods from the core countries, relegating them to semi-periphery instead of core status.<ref name=halsall/> So, while they had control over several peripheral regions and exploited them, a characteristic of a core region, these countries failed to develop the quality manufacturing industries and the access to international banking that further defined core countries, leaving them a step below in the world system at semi-periphery status.<ref name=halsall/>
===1700–1875=== [[File:graph rel share world manuf 1750 1900 02.png|300px|thumb|As the Industrial Revolution developed British manufactured output surged ahead of other economies]] The development of trade between Europe, the Americas, and the East generated massive profits for a relatively small [[merchant]] elite in the European colonial powers.<ref name=halsall/> These merchants were able to utilize their profits to take control of [[agriculture]] and other industries.<ref name=halsall/> The merchant class further consolidated its power by extending control over internal markets and the prices of finished goods.<ref name=halsall/> The end result was the development of the necessary capital to [[industrialize]] the European core states.<ref name=halsall/>
This era was defined by the transition from agriculture to [[industrialization]].<ref name=halsall/> The rapid development of industry triggered several reactions. Many European states explored new territories in addition to their original colonial holdings for new markets to exploit.<ref name=halsall/> The European world system continued to expand and include more regions, as it absorbed the Indian Ocean economic system through the acquisition of colonies by Britain, France, Spain, and Portugal, among others.<ref name=halsall/> Previously isolated regions, like much of the American interior zone, joined newly independent South American countries in becoming part of the periphery.<ref name=halsall/> By the nineteenth century, Asia and Africa had also entered the world system as peripheral regions.<ref name=halsall/> This development of Africa and Asia as peripheral continents allowed for new cores like the United States and Germany to improve their core status, rising higher within the world system.<ref name=halsall/>
Throughout this time period was a constant shift within core regions from a combination of agriculture and industry to solely industrial enterprise.<ref name=halsall/> In this period, England was the leader in industrial and agricultural production, though by 1900, only ten percent of England's populace worked in agriculture, demonstrating the shift to industry not only in England but across the core stratum.<ref name=halsall/> The dramatic shift to industry extended beyond the core by the end of this time period, as core regions encouraged the development of [[manufacturing]] in peripheral and semi-peripheral zones to further develop those markets and create demand for newly developed machines and other goods.<ref name=halsall/>
===1875–1914=== [[File:Royal Irish Rifles ration party Somme July 1916.jpg|thumb|A ration party of the Royal Irish Rifles in a communication trench.]] The [[West]] represented both the core and the semi-periphery, as Europe dominated 80% of the world's market share.<ref name="Hobsbawn">Hobsbawn, Eric. 1987.</ref> Much of the rest of the world was a diverse periphery, though Japan was a notable exception.<ref name="Hobsbawn"/> As expansionism continued, new core nations emerged, such as the Britain, Germany, and the United States, while old cores such as Spain and Portugal faded to the semi-periphery.<ref name="Hobsbawn"/> The growth of the power of the common man led to an expansion of thought concerning democracy, communism, and revolution, which pervaded the weaker semi-peripheral nations overcome with civil distress.<ref name="Hobsbawn"/> In some cases, this led to the weakening of the nations, such as the violent revolution in France.<ref name="Hobsbawn"/> This contributed to the adoption of totalitarian leaders, as seen in Germany and France.<ref name="Hobsbawn"/> The major factors contributing to world war were the conflicts and power struggles taking place between the three classes of nations in the global system.<ref name="Hobsbawn"/> Nations considered part of the semi-periphery felt oppressed by the stronger, larger core nations.<ref name="Hobsbawn"/>
===1914–today=== [[File:Royal Air Force Bomber Command, 1942-1945. CL3400.jpg|thumb|Burned-out buildings after the [[Bombing of Hamburg in World War II|bombing of Hamburg]]]] {{Unreferenced section|date=June 2010}} This trend known to continued throughout the century, with Germany, Russia, and Japan also taking seats at the core. At the end of World War II however, Germany quickly fell to the [[semi-periphery]] along with war-ravaged France. As the rest of Europe struggled to rebuild itself, it also fell to the [[semi-periphery]], with the exception of many [[Eastern European]] nations, who fell under the Soviet Union as bloc countries. Japan also fell back into semi-periphery, along with the industrializing China and India, until their recent upswing in influence. Change also came to North America, where [[American imperialism]] led to the rise of countries like [[Guatemala]] and the [[Dominican Republic]]. On the other side of the Pacific, Australia was also developing, helping to secure an Allied Victory in World War II.
===Today=== [[File:Imf-advanced-un-least-developed-2008.svg|thumb|400px|{{legend|#0000ff|Advanced economies}} {{legend|#ff9000|Emerging and developing economies (not least developed)}} {{legend|#ff0000|Emerging and developing economies ([[least developed country|least developed]])}}Classifications by the [[International Monetary Fund|IMF]] and the [[United Nations|UN]]]]
[[File:2014 UN Human Development Report Quartiles.svg|thumb|right|400px|World map indicating the category of Human Development Index by country (based on 2014 update). {{div col|colwidth=30em}} {{Legend|#003399|Very High}} {{Legend|#3072D9|High}} {{Legend|#A8C3FF|Medium}} {{Legend|#E6EDFF|Low}} {{Legend|#858585|Data unavailable}} {{div col end}}]]
In today's global hierarchy, some states are transitioning upward while others are moving downward in terms of status and influence. Former colonial powers no longer exercise control over an international domain and are instead mostly relegated to their core; for example, former European world powers do not exert influence over colonial outposts in the [[Americas]], Africa, or Asia, but rather have consolidated their power in the form of the [[European Union]].<ref name="shaw">Shaw, Timothy M. ''The Review of Black Political Economy'': pp. 341-358. [http://www.springerlink.com/content/2118h2x63n84u170/]</ref> The new leading powers are mostly non-European (United States, Canada, Japan). Outside of these developed countries are countries (see list below) that are considered semi-periphery and are both dominant and dominated within economic, political, and social realms.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Morales Ruvalcaba|first1=Daniel Efrén|title=INSIDE THE BRIC: ANALYSIS OF THE SEMIPERIPHERAL NATURE OF BRAZIL, RUSSIA, INDIA AND CHINA|journal=Austral: Brazilian Journal of Strategy & International Relations|date=11 September 2013|volume=2|issue=4|url=http://seer.ufrgs.br/index.php/austral/article/view/40942/26976|language=es|issn=2238-6912}}</ref> These middle powers are a combination of nations that have emerged as a result of the fragmentation of the Soviet Union and nations that have risen because of their possession of resources in high demand, like oil in [[Saudi Arabia]].<ref name="shaw"/> While these nations are by no means on the level of the stated world powers, they are able to exert influence over the weaker nations of the impoverished [[Fourth World]].<ref name="shaw"/>
Other terms used to describe semi-periphery countries include sub-imperial and semi-industrial.<ref name="shaw"/> [[Immanuel Wallerstein]] identifies three ways by which countries can emerge from the periphery into the semi-periphery.<ref name="shaw"/> Countries with a large market and room for industrial growth, like [[Brazil]], South Africa, and Mexico, and countries with valuable energy resources, like [[Iran]] and Saudi Arabia, can utilize the strategy of seizing the chance.<ref name="shaw"/> The strategy of promotion by invitation can be utilized by countries willing to be open to foreign governmental and regional administrative centers.<ref name="shaw"/> Examples of past countries to utilize this strategy are the capitalist regimes in Africa like [[Egypt]], [[Kenya]], [[Nigeria]], [[Zaire]], [[Senegal]], and [[Côte d'Ivoire]].<ref name="shaw"/> These countries use [[dependency theory|dependent development]] to integrate into the world economy and establish local dominance.<ref name="shaw"/> Outside of these strategies is that of self-reliance, a basic theory that as some countries grow, others will decline.<ref name="shaw"/> Many countries in Africa and South America have exhibited the qualities of a sub-imperial or semi-industrial power.<ref name="shaw"/>
Wallerstein examines the role of semi-periphery countries during a period of economic downturn.<ref name=waller2/> To redefine core and periphery countries in an economic sense, core countries are characterized by advanced technology, high [[Profit (economics)|profits]], high wages, and diversified production while periphery countries have less technology, low profits, low wages, and less diversified production.<ref name=waller2/> Semi-periphery countries fall in the middle of these spectra, and their unique political and social structure place them in a position where they can best take advantage of economic downturns.<ref name=waller2/>
These economic downturns occur because of increased [[supply (economics)|supply]] and decreased [[demand]], which combine to create a shift in surplus and power to the semi-periphery. Semi-periphery regions take advantage of the situation by expanding control of their home markets and the surrounding periphery countries at the expense of core countries.<ref name=waller2/> The underlying reason for this shift in power lies in the basic economic principle of [[scarcity]]. As long as core countries maintain scarcities of their goods, they can select customers from semi-periphery and periphery countries that are competing over them. When excess supply occurs, the core countries are the ones competing over a smaller market. This competition allows semi-peripheral nations to select from among core countries rather than vice versa when making decisions about commodity purchases, manufacturing investments, and sales of goods, shifting the balance of power to the semi-periphery.<ref name=waller2/> While in general there is a power shift from core to semi-periphery in times of economic struggles, there are few examples of semi-peripheral countries transitioning to core status.<ref name=waller2/> To accomplish this, semi-peripheral nations must not only take advantage of weaker core countries but must also exploit any existing advantages over other semi-peripheral nations.<ref name=waller2/> How well they exploit these advantages determines their arrangement within the semi-periphery class.<ref name=waller2/>
==Effects== [[File:Election MG 3455.JPG|thumb|A ballot box]] The semi-peripheral nations of the world have played an important role to world trade and interaction since early periods of globalized trade. This "middle ground" between the very powerful [[Core countries|cores]] and the backwaters of the far [[Periphery countries|periphery]] allowed those two zones to interact with greater ease. For example, during the [[Pax Mongolica|13th-century world system]], the semi-periphery areas around Europe's Mediterranean Coast facilitated trade between the peripheries of the more manufacturing based [[Flanders|Northern Europe]] and the cores of India and China.<ref name=abu/> John Markoff, a [[sociology|sociologist]] at the [[University of Pittsburgh]], also notes that political developments, particularly in the advancement of [[democracy]], originate in the semi-periphery.<ref name="Markoff"/> He notes that innovations in democracy came from the semi-periphery rather than the more established, stable [[First World|core nations]], where profit discourages great reform, or the extremely poor [[Third World|periphery]] where instability makes reform too dangerous to attempt.<ref name="Markoff"/> It has been within semi-peripheral nations where democratic reforms like the expansion of suffrage and the institution of the secret ballot have been implemented.<ref name="Markoff">Markoff, John. 1999-1041:4</ref>

{{Infobox Radio Show | show_name = The Flattery Show | image = | imagesize = 150px | caption = | other_names = | format = [[Talk show|Talk]] | runtime = Sundays 5pm-7pm [[Central European Time|CET]] | country = France | language = English | home_station = Radio Coteaux | syndicates = | television = | starring = John Slattery & Patricia McKinnes | creator = | writer = | director = | producer = Patrick Martinez | newsreader = | sportreader = | executive_producer = | narrated = | record_location = Radio Coteaux Studios, [[Saint-Blancard]] | first_aired = 6 February 2011 | last_aired = | num_series = | num_episodes = | audio_format = FM and Digital radio | opentheme = | endtheme = | website = [http://www.flatteryshow.com Official website] | podcast = [http://www.flatteryshow.com/podcasts/FlatteryShowPodcasts.xml Official podcast] }}
'''''The Flattery Show''''' was the first [[English-language radio]] [[chat show]] aired in the south west of [[France]] and a flagship Sunday evening programme broadcast on [[Radio Coteaux]] in the [[Gascony]] region. The show was presented by Irish radio presenter John Slattery with American co-host Patricia McKinnes. It ran for twenty-one weeks and proved to be very popular with expatriates living in France.
==The show==
Slattery and McKinnes regularly began the show at 5pm and finished at 7pm with a handover to Patrick Martinez. ''The Flattery Show'' was a music-based programme that included light-hearted banter and whimsical jokes by the hosts. Listeners' views and comments were discussed and there were rotating segments such as "Song of The Week", "Ask a Frenchie" and "Life in the South-West". To keep listeners on their toes, random topics were picked from a big "Bag O' Topics".
==Invited guests==
The show ran interviews with regular and/or rotating guests, dealing with subjects of both local interest and of general interest to the [[expatriate]] community. The first people to be interviewed on the show were the English sisters Marcha King and Sian Cash, former proprietors of the landmark café "Bar Memory" in the [[Hautes-Pyrénées]] town of [[Castelnau-Magnoac]]. They recounted humorous stories of their years behind the bar at the French café. The interview proved enormously popular with English-speaking listeners in France and it served to create a pattern of jesting and buffoonery that would become an underlying trait of later interviews.
==Regular contributors==
The show relied heavily on e-mailed material sent in by listeners that was then read out on air. Most of the regular contributors were local expatriates living in the Gascony region.
==The end==
The show ran for twenty-one weeks in the early months of 2011. When it ceased, Radio Coteaux's Sunday evening slot was filled by a new show called ''[[The Gascony Show]]'', also hosted by John Slattery.
==External links== *[http://www.flatteryshow.com ''The Flattery Show'' home page] *[http://www.gasconyshow.com ''The Gascony Show'' home page] *[http://www.radiocoteaux.com Radio Coteaux] *[http://www.ladepeche.fr/article/2011/03/19/1038444-So-british-sur-radio-Coteaux.html «So british» sur radio Coteaux] ''La Dêpeche'', 19 March 2011

{{update|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox islands | name = The World Islands (Dubai) | native_name = <!-- or local name to remove the "native name:" prefix --> | sobriquet = <!-- or nickname --> | image_name = Dubaiworld.jpg | image_size = 250px | image_caption = View of The World in early 2009 | image_alt = | map_image = Dubai new developments.png | map_size = 300 | map_caption = | location = [[United Arab Emirates]] | coordinates = {{coord|25|13|00|N|55|10|00|E|display=inline,title}} | archipelago = The World | total_islands = | major_islands = | area_km2 = <!-- or area m2 or area ha --> | area_footnotes = | rank = | length_km = 9 | width_km = 6 | width_footnotes = | coastline_km = <!-- or coastline m --> | coastline_footnotes = | elevation_m = | elevation_footnotes = | highest_mount = <!--name--> | country = [[United Arab Emirates]] | demonym = | population = | population_as_of = | density_km2 = | density_footnotes = | ethnic_groups = | website = {{URL|www.nakheel.com}} | additional_info = '''Developer:''' [[Nakheel]] }} [[File:The world Dubai.jpg|thumb|right|450px|The development's logo]] '''The World''' or '''The World Islands, located in Dubai,''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]]: جزر العالم; ''Juzur al-Ālam'') is an [[Artificial island|artificial]] [[archipelago]] of various small [[island]]s constructed in the rough shape of a [[world map]], located in the waters of the [[Persian Gulf]], {{Convert|4.0|km|mi}} off the coast of [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]].<ref name="Progress Update">{{cite web|url=http://www.ameinfo.com/133896.html |publisher=''[[AMEInfo]]'' |title=Dubai's Palm and World Islands - progress update |date=2007-10-04 |accessdate=2008-02-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011022845/http://www.ameinfo.com/133896.html |archivedate=2007-10-11 |df= }}</ref> The World islands are composed mainly of sand [[dredging|dredged]] from Dubai's shallow coastal waters, and are one of several [[artificial island]] developments in Dubai.<ref name="Progress Update"/> The World's developer is [[Nakheel Properties]], and the project was originally conceived by [[Sheikh]] [[Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum]], the ruler of Dubai. The actual construction was done by two Dutch (joint venture) specialist companies, Van Oord and Boskalis. The same companies also created the [[Palm Jumeirah]].
Construction of the 300 islands began in 2003, only to halt due to the [[2008 financial crisis]].<ref name="Sinking">{{cite news|title='The World' is sinking|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/travel/international/4594274/The-World-is-sinking|accessdate=28 January 2011|newspaper=The Age|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> Though 60 percent of the islands had been sold off to private contractors back in 2008, development on most of these islands has failed to initiate.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Schaffer|first1=Sierra|title=The "World" Is Sinking Back Into The Sea, Dubai's World Islands That Is – TechMalak|url=https://www.techmalak.com/the-world-is-sinking-back-into-the-sea-dubais-world-that-is/#.WS2awHXyukA|work=TechMalak|date=23 May 2016}}</ref> As of July 2012, the Lebanon Island was developed and was the only island that had so far been developed commercially, being used for private corporate events and public parties. As of late 2013, only two of the islands had been developed. In January 2014, Kleindienst Group announced the launch of "The Heart of Europe" project;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jk-properties.com/newsletters/january2014/ |title= KLEINDIENST GROUP LAUNCHES ICONIC THE HEART OF EUROPE PROJECT|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= January 2014 |publisher= JK Properties |accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref> by February 2014, one of Kleindienst Group's brands - JK Properties - announced in their monthly newsletter that the project was "well underway".<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.jk-properties.com/newsletters/february2014/ |title= WORK CONTINUES TO PROGRESS AT A PACE ON THE HEART OF EUROPE |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= February 2014 |publisher= JK Properties |accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref> The first of these series of islands will be Europe, Sweden and Germany with development led by Kleindienst Group.
==Project== Islands in the project range from {{convert|14000|to|42000|m2|sqft}} in area.<ref name="Progress Update"/> Distances between islands average {{convert|100|m|ft}}; they are constructed from {{convert|321,000,000|m3|abbr=out}} of sand and 386 million tons of rock.<ref name="Progress Update"/> Designed by [[Creative Kingdom Dubai]], the development is an area that covers {{convert|6|by|9|km|mi}} and is surrounded by an oval-shaped [[Breakwater (structure)|breakwater]] island. Roughly {{convert|232|km|abbr=on}} of shoreline was created. The World's overall development costs were estimated at $13 billion [[Canadian Dollar|CAD]] in 2005.
The archipelago consists of seven sets of islands; [[Europe]], [[Africa]], [[Asia]], [[North America]], [[South America]], [[Antarctica]], and [[Oceania]].<ref name="Atlas Obscura 2016">{{cite web | title=The World Islands | website=Atlas Obscura | date=September 26, 2016 | url=http://www.atlasobscura.com/places/world-islands | access-date=July 8, 2018}}</ref> Each artificial islands are named for their representative regions, including those representing [[countries]], [[landmarks]], and [[regions]] such as the [[United Kingdom]],<ref>{{OSM|w|186483481|United Kingdom}} {{coord|25.22334|N|55.15937|E|format=dec|name=United Kingdom}}</ref> [[California]],<ref>{{OSM|r|2713321|California|tools=short}} {{coord|25.20300|N|55.14376|E|format=dec|name=California}}</ref> [[Mount Everest]],<ref>{{OSM|w|87185503|Mount Everest}} {{coord|25.23683|N|55.17535|E|format=dec|name=Mount Everest}}</ref> [[Australia]],<ref>{{OSM|w|87185938|Australia}} {{coord|25.23149|N|55.19435|E|format=dec|name=Australia}}</ref> [[New Mexico]],<ref>{{OSM|r|8402261|New Mexico}} {{coord|25.201379|N|55.151797|E|format=dec|name=New Mexico}}</ref> [[Upernavik]],<ref>{{OSM|w|87184344|Upernavik}} {{coord|25.22142|N|55.13939|E|format=dec|name=Upernavik}}</ref> [[Buenos Aires]],<ref>{{OSM|w|202033673|Buenos Aires}} {{coord|25.20106|N|55.1695|E|format=dec|name=Buenos Aires}}</ref> [[New York (state)|New York]],<ref>{{OSM|w|87184265|New York}} {{coord|25.21421|N|55.15101|E|format=dec|name=New York}}</ref> [[Mexico]],<ref>{{OSM|r|8402263|Mexico}} {{coord|25.201824|N|55.154394|E|format=dec|name=Mexico}}</ref> [[St. Petersburg]]<ref>{{OSM|w|200489433|St. Petersburg}} {{coord|25.23475|N|55.16479|E|format=dec|name=St. Petersburg}}</ref> and [[India]].<ref>{{OSM|w|170773643|India}} {{coord|25.23110|N|55.1796|E|format=dec|name=India}}</ref>
==History== The project was unveiled in May 2003 by Sheikh Mohammed<ref name="AB">{{cite web |url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/507983-the-world-islands-in-dubai-completed |publisher=''ArabianBusiness.com'' |title=The World islands in Dubai complete |date=2008-01-10 |accessdate=2008-02-02}}</ref> and dredging began four months later in September 2003.<ref name="AB"/> By January 2008, 60% of the islands were sold, 20 of which were bought in the first four months of 2007.<ref name="Progress Update"/><ref name="AB"/> On 10 January 2008 the final stone on the breakwater was laid, completing development of the archipelago.<ref name="AB"/> As of July 2012, a second island, the Lebanon Island was developed and was 'the only island that has so far been developed commercially, is used for private corporate events and public parties.' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/uae-news/the-world-is-back-on-dubais-map|title=The World is back on Dubai's map|author=Colin Simpson|publisher=|accessdate=18 April 2016}}</ref>
==Project difficulties== [[The Times]] Online reported in September 2009 that work on The World had been suspended due to the effects of the [[Financial crisis of 2007–2010|global financial crisis]].<ref name="creditcrunch">{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/travel/news/article6831481.ece|title=Credit crunch signals end of The World for Dubai’s multi-billion dollar property deal|publisher=Times Online UK|date=September 12, 2009|accessdate=2009-11-28 | location=London | first=James | last=McLean}}</ref><ref name="darkside">{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/johann-hari/the-dark-side-of-dubai-1664368.html |title=The dark side of Dubai |author=Johann Hari |publisher=The Independent |date=2009-04-07 |accessdate=2009-05-16 | location=London }}</ref> And in February 2010 the [[Daily Mail]] reported that the islands had started sinking back into the sea.<ref name=Bates>{{Citation | title = Is it the end of the world? Nasa picture suggests Dubai globe is sinking back into the sea | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-1247651/World-Islands-Is-end-world-Nasa-picture-suggests-Dubai-globe-sinking-sea.html | author = Bates, Claire | journal = Daily Mail | accessdate = 2010-04-07 | date=2010-02-02 | location=London }}</ref> This was later denied by Nakheel and independent technical reports as wholly inaccurate.<ref name="McGinley">{{cite web |url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/580782-island-owners-hit-back-at-sinking-claims |title=Island owners hit back at 'sinking' claims |author= Shane McGinley |publisher=arabianbusiness |date=2010-02-04 |accessdate=2010-02-04 }}</ref> Despite the denial, [[The Daily Telegraph]] reported in January 2011 that an independent company, Penguin Marine, provided verification on the erosion of the islands and the silting of the passageways between the islands.<ref name=Penguin>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/dubai/8271643/The-World-is-sinking-Dubai-islands-falling-into-the-sea.html |title=The World is sinking: Dubai islands 'falling into the sea' |publisher = The Daily Telegraph |date=2011-01-20 |accessdate=2011-01-25 |location=London |first=Richard |last=Spencer}}</ref> Due to finance and technical problems, Penguin Marine, the company contracted to provide transportation to the archipelago, is attempting to get out of the annual fees of $1.6 million paid to Nakheel properties.<ref name =Penguin/>
As of early 2011, only one of the islands had been occupied by a building (a show home) on it,<ref name=Sinking/> and commercial or residential properties were not currently being constructed on any of the other islands. Property prices in the Emirates had fallen 58 percent from their peak in the fourth quarter of 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=The End of The World|url=http://english.kompas.com/read/2011/01/23/03401537/The.End.of.The.World|work=Kompas.com|accessdate=6 January 2012}}</ref> The world economic recovery from the [[Great Recession]] has resulted in a rebound for the Dubai real estate market: it has been reported that "residential prices [in Dubai] rose by 17.9% from August 2012 to 2013, while rents soared by 14.9% in the same period." <ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.jk-properties.com/newsletters/november2013/|title=JK Properties Monthly Newsletter (Nov. 2013) "A BRIGHT OUTLOOK FOR DUBAI’S PROPERTY MARKET" |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=November 2013 |publisher=JK Properties |accessdate=14 March 2014}}</ref>
Irish investor/businessman John O'Dolan, who purchased the "Ireland" island, committed suicide in February 2009, after his consortium fell into financial difficulty.<ref>{{Citation | title = Extravagant Dubai island project sinks under weight of the credit crunch | url = http://www.independent.ie/world-news/middle-east/extravagant-dubai-island-project-sinks-under-weight-of-the-credit-crunch-1884856.html | date = September 12, 2009 | journal = Irish Independent | last1 = McLean | first1 = James | last2 = McDonald | first2 = Brian | accessdate = 2010-04-07 }}</ref>
==Purchase and development plans== [[File:2010 The World.JPG|thumb|The World 2010 (airview)]]
The World was supposed to be serviced by four major transportation hubs linked by waterways. Land parcels are supposedly zoned for various uses: estate, mid density, high density, resorts and commercial.<ref name="video">{{cite web|url=http://www.theworld.ae/videoGallery.html | title=The World Video Gallery|author=Nakheel}}</ref> A Dubai Infinity Holdings construction planner has stated that developers have been negotiating with Nakheel about temporary siting of a cement batching plant on one of the islands to supply subdivided construction.<ref name="national3quarters">{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/property/the-world-three-quarters-sold-out|title=‘The World’ three-quarters sold out|author=The National Newspaper}}</ref>
The plan was for utilities to be routed under water, with water plants at each of the hubs pumping fresh water to the islands. Power was to be supplied by the Dubai Grid and distributed through underwater cables, however as of February 2015 no cables had been laid, so that developers currently have to provide their own power from diesel generators. Waste water and refuse systems are an individual concern for each island.<ref name="video"/>
Nakheel Group is itself further developing a resort named Coral Island over 20 islands that make up the North American part of The World. The low-rise development will include a marina and hotel village.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uaeinteract.com/docs/Nakheel_unveils_super-luxury_resort_at_Coral_Island_of_The_World/25125.htm|title=Nakheel unveils super-luxury resort at Coral Island of The World |date=2007-03-05|publisher=National Media Council UAE|accessdate=2008-03-26}}</ref> The second largest confirmed development is the purchase of 14 islands that make up Australia and New Zealand by Investment Dar of [[Kuwait]]. The islands are being [[terraforming|terraformed]] to be developed as a resort named [[OQYANA]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asiatraveltips.com/news05/134-TheWorld.shtml|title=Nakheel sells Australasia segment of The World|date=2005-04-13|publisher=AsiaTravelTips.com|accessdate=2006-12-29}}</ref>
Irish business consortium Larionovo had plans to develop the [[Ireland]] island into an Irish-themed resort.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theislandofireland.com/|title=The Island of Ireland|accessdate=2007-07-23}}</ref> The plans include a large internal marina, apartments and villas, a gym, hotel, and an Irish-themed pub. In July 2007 it was announced that the Ireland Island would feature a recreation of [[Northern Ireland]]'s [[Giant's Causeway]]. However, on 25 November 2008 a provisional liquidator was appointed to Larionovo.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.larionovo.com/ |title=Larionovo }}</ref> The islands of [[Great Britain]] and [[Moscow]] on The World were acquired by Premier Real Estate Bureau in the Summer of 2008. News was leaked in a [[Daily Mail]] article of January 2009, refuting claims that Great Britain was owned by [[Richard Branson]], [[Rod Stewart]] or John O'Dolan.<ref>{{cite news |title=Homesick Balham boy buys Britain-shaped island for £43m |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1120695/Homesick-Balham-boy-buys-Britain-shaped-island-43m--8211-London-pub.html |publisher=Daily Mail|accessdate=2009-04-08 | first=Martin | last=Delgado | date=2009-01-17}}</ref>
In April 2008, Salya Corporation announced that it had acquired the islands of Finland and Brunei in The World and planned to develop them into fashion-themed resorts. Salya spent about [[United Arab Emirates dirham|Dh]]800 million ($218 million USD) to purchase the islands and plans to spend a further Dh2.4 billion ($654 million USD) on development. Brunei Island will be turned into a [[Fashion TV]] resort and Finland Island will be turned into a fashion community called FTV palace.<ref>{{cite web |title=World's Finland and Brunei to be hub of fashion |url=http://www.business24-7.ae/articles/2008/4/pages/worldhub.aspx |publisher=Emirates Business 24/7 |date=2008-04-24 |accessdate=2008-04-27}}</ref>
Safi Qurashi, the seven-time multi-millionaire entrepreneur <ref>Leftly, Mark. ''Anger over pay is just the free market in action'', [[The Independent]] 10 June 2012</ref> at the head of Premier, and his business partner Mustafa Nagri, paid an estimated $64 million USD for the {{convert|11|acre|ha|adj=on|order=flip}} piece of land; he was later convicted for non-payment of cheques and sentenced to seven years in jail.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jul/23/dubai-safi-qurashi | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Rajeev | last=Syal | title=Owner of Dubai's 'little Britain' jailed for non-payment of cheques | date=2010-07-23}}</ref> However, on appeal he was later found not guilty and released from prison in July 2012 when he was declared innocent of two of the three charges.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/exclusive-two-safi-qurashi-judgements-quashed-466985.html | location=Dubai | work=Arabian Business | first=Shane | last=McGinley | title=EXCLUSIVE: Two Safi Qurashi judgements quashed | date=2012-07-23}}</ref> and <ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/personalfinance/expat-money/9423555/Briton-Safi-Qurashi-has-convictions-overturned-in-Dubai.html | location=London | work=The Telegraph | first=Leah | last=Hyslop | title=Briton Safi Qurashi has convictions overturned in Dubai | date=2012-07-24}}</ref> On the final charges the civil court final judgment showed he owed no money, was a victim of fraud and vindicated him completely by awarding 10.8 Million USD to be paid back to him by his former partner who had defrauded him.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/dubai-s-safi-qurashi-cleared-of-bouncing-2-7m-cheque-489328.html | location=Dubai | work=Arabian Business | first=Claire | last=Valdini | title=Dubai's Safi Qurashi cleared of bouncing $2.7m cheque | date=2013-02-13}}</ref> and <ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/safi-qurashi-s-former-partner-ordered-repay-10-8m-by-dubai-court-529323.html | location=Dubai | work=Arabian Business | first=Ashford | last=Fernandez | title=Safi Qurashi’s former partner ordered to repay $10.8m by Dubai court | date=2013-12-04}}</ref> Safi Qurashi is still the owner of GB Island and continues to live and run his businesses in Dubai and is still confident of developing the Island of GB into a unique destination.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.constructionweekonline.com/article-32193-interview-not-the-end-of-the-world-safi-qurashi/ | location=Dubai | work=Construction Week | first=Hannah | last=Raven | title=Interview: Not the End of the World, Safi Qurashi | date=2015-01-17}}</ref>
Josef Kleindienst and his firm JK Properties are developing The Heart of Europe, a collection of seven islands (Germany, Netherlands, Sweden, St. Petersburg, Main Europe, Switzerland and Monaco) in the European section of the World, into an island luxury resort.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Heart of Europe|url=http://www.thoe.com/|accessdate=14 February 2016}}</ref> The resort is meant to create a fully immersive European experience, with outdoor snow,<ref>{{cite news|title=Heart of Europe in Dubai: Streets with snow|url=http://www.emirates247.com/property/heart-of-europe-in-dubai-streets-with-snow-2014-01-20-1.535342|accessdate=14 February 2016|publisher=Emirates 24/7|date=20 January 2014}}</ref> and stores accepting only the EURO as a currency.<ref>{{cite news|title=VIDEO: Plans to make it snow in Dubai are not a gimmick, says CEO|url=http://7days.ae/plans-make-snow-dubai-not-gimmick-says-ceo|accessdate=14 February 2016|publisher=7Days}}</ref>
==Timeline of construction== {{See also|List of Developments on The World Islands}} [[File:The World on 1 May 2007 Pict 4.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Undeveloped islands on 1 May 2007]]
[[File:The World Archipelago April 2015.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Undeveloped islands on 11 April 2015]]
*May 2003: The World development was announced by Nakheel, total completion scheduled for 2008. It was initially to have 200 islands and an area of {{convert|60000000|sqft|m2|order=flip}}.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com">{{cite web|author=Dubai FAQs |url=http://www.dubaifaqs.com/the-world-dubai.php |title=The World Dubai |publisher=Dubaifaqs.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> *February 2004: It was announced that The World would comprise 260 islands, and its area would be 6 km by 9 km, with an area of {{convert|250|-|900000|sqft|m2|order=flip}} for each island, with {{convert|50|-|100|m|ft|abbr=on}} of water between each island.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *August 2004: It was announced that land reclamation would cost at AED 7.3 billion ($2 billion).<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *April 2005: Sand dredging 55 percent complete, 88 islands had been completed.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *30 March 2006: [[Richard Branson]] appeared at a media conference on the [[Great Britain]] island. However, this was to announce direct [[London]]-to-[[Dubai]] flights by [[Virgin Atlantic]], and was not related to his investing in the project.<ref>{{cite web|author=smh |url=http://www.asiatraveltips.com/news06/303-TheWorld.shtml |title=Sir Richard Branson 'Stakes his Claim' on The World in Dubai |publisher=Asiatraveltips.com |date=2006-03-30 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> *October 2006: Seven-time [[Formula One]] World Champion [[Michael Schumacher]] was presented with one of the islands by Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum on the occasion of his final [[Grand Prix motor racing|Grand Prix]], in Brazil. Schumacher's manager [[Willi Weber]], suggested, "Perhaps he'll build a [[kart racing]] track on [the island].<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *December 2006: The World reclamation 90 percent complete.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *October 2007: Nakheel announced the sale of Ireland, and Shanghai in October 2007.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *15 November 2007: [[Brad Pitt]] and [[Angelina Jolie]] were reported to have purchased the island ''Ethiopia''{{according to whom|date=December 2015}}. Guest and residential villas and a hospitality complex are planned.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.europe-re.com/system/main.php?pageid=2343&articleid=10631 |title=Cinnovation acquires Nova Island on The World (UAE/SG) |publisher=Europe-re.com |date=2010-06-01 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> [[File:Artificial Archipelagos, Dubai, United Arab Emirates ISS022-E-024940 lrg.jpg|thumb|left|Artificial archipelagos, [[Dubai]], United Arab Emirates]] *25 February 2008: Dubai Multi Commodities Centre announced that it will establish a {{convert|6000|m2|sqft|adj=on}} [[pearl hunting|pearling]] and marine entertainment center in association with Paspaley Pearling Corporation. It will be located on an island in the Antarctic region of The World.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ameinfo.com/148011.html |title=Dubai unveils 'Pearls of Arabia' at The World | DMCC |publisher=AMEinfo.com |date=2012-06-20 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> *September 2008: Dubai's Limitless announced plans to develop a $161 million USD wellness resort on an island in "Siberia". Pearl Dubai paid $27.2 million USD for a {{convert|1600000|sqft|m2|adj=on|order=flip}} island nearby.<ref name="thenational.ae"/> *28 December 2008: Turkey Island was bought by MNG Holding in June 2008 for $19 million USD.<ref name="thenational.ae">{{cite web|author=- Saturday |url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/property/the-world-three-quarters-sold-out |title='The World' three-quarters sold out - The National |publisher=Thenational.ae |date=2012-06-06 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> *28 December 2008: China's Zhongzhou International announced that it will be developing a hotel resort on Shanghai island.<ref name="thenational.ae"/> *28 December 2008: Nakheel said 70 percent of The World had been sold.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *October 2009: An Emirates Business report on 13 October 2009 that 2 islands were sold in July and August 2009.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *December 2009: Dubai based Kleindienst Group said they would start construction of the Heart of Europe in early 2010, according to a press report of 17 December 2009. Islands include Austria, Germany, Netherlands, St Petersburg, Sweden and Switzerland.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *January 2010: On 28 January 2010 Emirates Business reported that Major Trade had started development of their projects on an island in the Greenland area, a villa and hotel resort.<ref name="dubaifaqs.com"/> *23 February 2010: Dubai-based Kleindienst Group started work on the Germany island of The World, according to a press release on 24 February 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ameinfo.com/225097.html |title=First developer breaks ground on The World | Real Estate |publisher=AMEinfo.com |date=2012-06-20 |accessdate=2012-07-07}}</ref> [[File:The World islands map.svg|thumb|300px|The World islands map, annotated with existing developments]] *17 July 2012: The Royal Island Beach Club opened on Lebanon Island. *6 May 2013: Nakheel announces that an out of court settlement has been reached between itself and developer Kleindienst Group, allowing construction on "The Heart of Europe" to resume.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nakheel.com/en/media/news/the-world-llc-settles-with-kleindienst-properties |title=The World LLC settles with Kleindienst Properties |author=<!--Staff writer(s); '''Time–space compression''' (also known as '''space–time compression''' and '''time–space distantiation'''), articulated in 1989 by geographer [[David Harvey (geographer)|David Harvey]] in ''The Condition of [[Postmodernity]]'',<ref>Harvey, David. ''The Condition of Postmodernity: An Enquiry into the Origins of Cultural Change''. Cambridge, MA: Blackwell, 1990.</ref> it refers to anything that impacts time and space. Harvey's idea was rooted in Karl Marx's theory of the "annihilation of time and space". A similar idea was proposed by [[Elmar Alvater]] in an article in ''[[PROKLA]]'' in 1987 translated into English as "Ecological and Economic Modalities of Time and Space" and published in ''[[Capitalism Nature Socialism]]'', 1(3) in 1989.
Time–space compression often occurs as a result of technological innovations including technology of communication and economics.
According to theorists like [[Paul Virilio]], time-space compression is an essential facet of contemporary life: "Today we are entering a space which is speed-space ... This new other time is that of electronic transmission, of high-tech machines, and therefore, man is present in this sort of time, not via his physical presence, but via programming" (qtd. in ''Decron'' 71<ref>Decron, Chris. ''Speed-Space.'' Virilio Live. Ed. John Armitage. London: Sage, 2001. 69–81.</ref>). In ''"Vitesse et Politique"'', Virilio coins the term '''dromology''' to describe "speed-space." Virilio describes velocity as the hidden side of wealth and power, which represents a determining factor concerning societies' structures. Historical eras and political events, out of this perspective, are also speed-ratios. In his view, acceleration destroys space and compresses the time in ways of perceiving reality.
[[Doreen Massey (geographer)|Doreen Massey]] maintains this idea about time-space compression in her discussion of globalization and its effect on our society. Similar to Virilio, she states that because our world is "speeding up" and "spreading out", time-space compression is more prevalent than ever as [[internationalization]] takes place. Cultures and communities are merged during time-space compression due to rapid growth and change, as "layers upon layers" of histories fuse together to shift our ideas of what the identity of a "place" should be.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Massey|first1=Doreen |authorlink=Doreen Massey (geographer)|chapter=A Global Sense of Place|title=Space, Place, and Gender|date=1994 |ISBN= 0816626162|publisher=[[University of Minnesota Press]]}}</ref>
Theorists generally identify two historical periods in which time–space compression occurred; the period from the mid-19th century to the beginnings of the [[First World War]], and the end of the 20th century. In both of these time periods, according to Jon May and Nigel Thrift, "there occurred a radical restructuring in the nature and experience of both time and space ... both periods saw a significant acceleration in the pace of life concomitant with a dissolution or collapse of traditional spatial co-ordinates".<ref>May, Jon and [[Nigel Thrift]]. "Introduction." ''TimeSpace: Geographies of Temporality''. NY: Routledge, 2001. pp. 1–46.</ref>
==Criticism==
For [[Moishe Postone]],<ref>[[Postone, Moishe]]. "Theorizing the Contemporary World: Robert Brenner, Giovanni Arrighi, David Harvey" in ''Political Economy of the Present and Possible Global Future(s)'', Anthem Press</ref> Harvey's treatment of space-time compression and postmodern diversity are as merely reactions to [[capitalism]]. Hence Harvey's analysis remains "extrinsic to the [[social form]]s expressed" by the deep structure concepts of capital, value and the [[commodity]].
For Postone the postmodern moment is not necessarily just a one-sided effect of the contemporary form of capitalism but can also be seen as having an emancipatory side if it happened to be part of a post-capitalism. And because postmodernism usually neglects its own context of embeddedness it can legitimate capitalism as postmodern, whereas at the level of deep structure it may in fact be more concentrated, with large capitals that, accumulate rather than diverge, and with an expansion of commodification niches with fewer buyers.
Postone asserts one cannot step outside capitalism and declare it a pure evil, or as a one-dimensional badness. For Postone, the [[emancipatory]] content of such things as equal distribution or diversity are potentials of capitalism itself in its abundant and diverse productive powers. It misfires however, when a form of life such as postmodernism takes itself for being the whole when in fact it is just another appearance of the same capitalist essence.
== References == {{reflist}} *{{cite book |last=Giddens |first=Anthony |authorlink=Anthony Giddens |title=A Contemporary Critique of Historical Materialism: Power, Property and the State |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5Dt6FY2Z2zgC |accessdate=23 May 2011 |year=1981 |publisher=Macmillan |location=London |isbn=978-0-520-04535-4 |pages=90–108 |chapter=Time-Space Distanciation and the Generation of Power}} * [[Jeff Lewis (professor)|Jeff Lewis]] (2008), ''[https://au.sagepub.com/en-gb/oce/cultural-studies/book229164 Cultural Studies]'', Sage, London. {{ISBN|9781412922302}}.

'''Transnational organization''' is a term used in scholarly literature. It refers to [[international organization]]s (usually, [[international nongovernmental organization]]s) that "transcend" the idea of a [[nation-state]].
The distinction between an international and a '''transnational organization''' is unclear and has been criticized by some scholars (ex. Colás, 2002).
Transnational relations have been defined as “contacts, coalitions, and interactions across state boundaries that are not controlled by the central foreign policy organs of governments.” Examples of transnational entities are “multinational business enterprises and revolutionary movements; trade unions and scientific networks; international air transport cartels and communications activities in outer space.” <ref>{{cite journal|last=Nye, Jr.|first=Joseph S.|author2=Robert O. Keohane|title=Transnational Relations and World Politics: An Introduction|journal=International Organization|year=1971|volume=25|issue=3|url=http://www.ucm.es/info/sdrelint/ficheros_materiales/materiales016.pdf|accessdate=27 November 2011|page=331|doi=10.1017/s0020818300026187}}</ref> Transnational social movements are “the broad tendencies that often manifest themselves in particular [[International non-governmental organization|International Non-Governmental Organizations (INGOs)]].” Examples of transnational social movements include human rights, women’s, peace, labor, green, or student movements manifested in [[Amnesty International]], the [[Peace Brigades International]], the [[International Confederation of Free Trade Unions]], etc.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cohen|first=Robin|title=Transnational social movements: an assessment|url=http://www.transcomm.ox.ac.uk/working%20papers/cohen.pdf|publisher=Department of Sociology, University of Warwick|accessdate=27 November 2011|page=2}}</ref> A further definition: “An organization is "transnational" rather than "national" if it carries on significant centrally-directed operations in the territory of two or more nation-states. Similarly, an organization will be called "international" rather than "national" only if the control of the organization is explicitly shared among representatives of two or more nationalities. And an organization is "multinational" rather than "national" only if people from two or more nationalities participate significantly in its operation.” <ref>{{cite journal|last=Huntington|first=Samuel|title=Transnational Organizations in World Politics|journal=World Politics|year=1973|volume=25|issue=3|jstor=2010115|page=336|publisher=Cambridge University Press}}</ref> “Transnational organizations are designed to facilitate the pursuit of a single interest within many national units.” <ref>{{cite journal|last=Huntington|first=Samuel|title=Transnational Organizations in World Politics|journal=World Politics|year=1973|volume=25|issue=3|jstor=2010115|page=338|publisher=Cambridge University Press}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Transnationalism]] *[[Transnationality]]
==References== * Archer, C. ''International Organizations''. London: Unwin Hyman. 1983 * Colás, Alejandro. ''International civil society: social movements in world politics.'' Wiley-Blackwell, 2002

{{Multiple issues| {{COI|date=August 2014}} {{NRIS-only|date=November 2013}} }} {{Infobox NRHP | name =Voice of America Bethany Relay Station | nrhp_type = | image = National VOA Museum of Broadcasting.jpg | caption = VOA Bethany Relay Station | location= 8070 Tylersville Road
[[West Chester Township, Butler County, Ohio|West Chester, Ohio]] | coordinates = {{coord|39|21|18|N|84|21|24|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Ohio#USA | area = | built =1944 | architect= | architecture= [[Art Deco]] | added = November 28, 2006 | governing_body = Local | refnum=06001081 {{NRISref|2008a}} }} [[File:Voice of America Bethany Relay Station.jpg|thumb|250px|The National Voice of America Museum of Broadcasting is the main building and campus of the original VOA, Bethany Relay Station.]] '''The [[Voice of America]]'s Bethany Relay Station''' was located in [[Butler County, Ohio]]'s [[West Chester Township, Butler County, Ohio|Union Township]] about 25 miles (40 km) north of [[Cincinnati, Ohio|Cincinnati]], adjacent to the transmitter site of [[WLW]]. Starting in 1944 during [[World War II]] it transmitted American radio programming abroad on [[shortwave]] frequencies, using 200,000-watt transmitters built by [[Crosley Broadcasting Corporation|Crosley]] engineers under the direction of R.J. Rockwell. The site was developed to provide 'fallback' transmission facilities inland and away from the East Coast, where transmitters were located in Massachusetts, on Long Island in New York, and in New Jersey, all close to the ocean, subject to attack from German submarines or other invading forces. Programming originated from studios in New York until 1954, when VOA headquarters moved to Washington. The station operated until 1994. The facility took its name from the [[Liberty Township, Butler County, Ohio|Liberty Township]] community of [[Bethany, Ohio|Bethany]], which was about two miles north of the facility. ==History== In 1943, the United States government bought nearly all of [[section (land)|Section]] 12 of Township 3, Range 2 of the [[Symmes Purchase]], the northeasternmost section of Union Township. From Hazel Beckley, 170 acres (688,000 m²) were purchased; from Philip Condon, 143 acres (579,000 m²); from Lola Gray Coy, 100 acres (405,000 m²); from John Miller, 69 acres (279,000 m²); and from Suzie Steinman, 142 acres (575,000 m²). The site was chosen for its elevation and its shallow bedrock and is today bounded by Tylersville Road on the south, Cox Road to the west, Liberty Way to the north, and [[Butler County, Ohio|Butler]]-[[Warren County, Ohio|Warren]] Road. The transmitters were built by [[Powel Crosley Jr.]]'s [[Crosley Broadcasting Corporation]] about one mile west of the company's tower for [[WLW-AM]] in [[Mason, Ohio|Mason]]. The [[Office of War Information]] began broadcasting in July 1944 and [[Adolf Hitler]] is said to have denounced the "Cincinnati liars". Following the war, with the OWI abolished, the facility was taken over by the [[United States Department of State|State Department]] in 1945. It became part of the newly created [[United States Information Agency]] in 1953. The Crosley Broadcasting Corporation operated the facility for the government until November 1963, when the Voice of America assumed direct control. At its peak the facility had six transmitters broadcasting with 250 kW and two transmitting with 50 kW. The facility was closed on November 14, 1994; because of changing technologies, the transmissions shifted to [[satellite]]s. The towers were brought down from December 1997 to February 1998. ==Post-closing use== Most of the land was turned over to the [[Butler County, Ohio|county]] and [[West Chester Township, Butler County, Ohio|township]] for use as a [[park]]. Part in the southwest corner was sold to developers who have erected a shopping center called the Voice of America Centre. The [[Miami University Voice of America Learning Center]] opened on the site in January 2009. ==National Voice of America Museum of Broadcasting== The 30,000 sq. ft. former Bethany Station building at 8070 Tylersville Road is being transformed into the National Voice of America Museum of Broadcasting, a historical center about the history of The Voice of America, radio and television. Using a blueprint developed by Jack Rouse Associates, the facility features displays and interactive experiences that relate the story of the Voice of America and incorporate other related collections from Media Heritage and the Gray History of Wireless Museum in [[Cincinnati]]. Displays include the radio station control room, re-creations of radio and television studios from the 1920s through the present, [[Old-time radio]] memorabilia and from the early days of television, and displays about area pioneers in the development of radio technology. An amateur radio club West Chester Amateur Radio Association, also operates a station using the callsign WC8VOA. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *Jim Blount. ''The 1900's: 100 Years In the History of [[Butler County, Ohio]].'' [[Hamilton, Ohio]]: Past Present Press, 2000. *Virginia I. Shewalter. ''A History of Union Township, Butler County, Ohio''. [West Chester, Ohio?]: The Author, 1979. * Stern, David & Banks, Michael, ''CROSLEY: Two Brothers and a Business Empire that Transformed the Nation'' [[Cincinnati, Ohio]]: Clerisy Press, 2006. ==External links== {{Commons category|Voice of America}} * [http://www.voamuseum.org National Voice of America Museum of Broadcasting] * [http://www.mediaheritage.com/museum/ Media Heritage: The Voice of America Museum of Broadcasting] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3w_ZXRJol_4 AmateurLogic Special Presentation on the VOA Museum] *[http://twit.tv/show/ham-nation/77 Bob Heil from Ham Nation takes a tour of the VOA Museum] {{National Register of Historic Places in Ohio}} {{NRHP in Butler County, Ohio}} [[Category:Government buildings on the National Register of Historic Places in Ohio]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Butler County, Ohio]] [[Category:National Register of Historic Places in Butler County, Ohio]] [[Category:International broadcasting]] [[Category:Radio stations in Ohio|*]] [[Category:Art Deco architecture in Ohio]] [[Category:1944 establishments in Ohio]] [[Category:1994 disestablishments in Ohio]] [[Category:Voice of America]] [[Category:Telecommunications buildings on the National Register of Historic Places]] [[Category:Short wave radio]]

The '''WBSC World Rankings''' is a ranking system for [[National sports team|national teams]] in [[baseball]] and [[softball]]. The teams of the member nations of the [[World Baseball Softball Confederation]] (WBSC), baseball's world governing body, are ranked based on their tournament results with the most successful teams being ranked highest. A point system is used, with points being awarded based on the results of WBSC-recognized international tournaments. Under the existing system, rankings are based on a team's performance over the last four years, with major international tournaments awarded a higher weighting compared to minor international and continental tournaments.
== History == In January 2009, the [[International Baseball Federation]] (IBAF) first published a listing in rank order of its member associations to provide a basis for comparison of the relative strengths of these teams. Though primarily focused on the respective men's senior teams of member nations, the current ranks also include points awarded based on results at the IBAF [[World Junior Baseball Championship|'AAA' (Under 18) Junior]] and [[World Youth Baseball Championship|'AA' (Under 16) Youth Championships]] held during the tracking period. Beginning in 2015, the rankings also determine which twelve teams participate in the [[WBSC Premier12]] tournament.
== Men's baseball rankings == {{em|For the current men's rankings, see chart at top of page and the WBSC website}}.<ref name="WBSC rankings">On the [http://www.wbsc.org WBSC website], '''click on''' "Menu" and then click on "Rankings." Retrieved 2016-10-22.</ref>

{| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%; float: right; clear:right; margin-left: 1em; text-align:center;" |- !colspan=4|Women's Baseball Rankings as of 19 September 2017<ref name="world rankings"/> |- ! Rank !! Team !!Points !! Confederation {{IBAF World Rankings row|w=y|r=1|t=JPN|p=2000|c=BFA}} {{IBAF World Rankings row|w=y|r=2|t=CAN|p=1333|c=COPABE}} {{IBAF World Rankings row|w=y|r=3|t=USA|p=1180|c=COPABE}} {{IBAF World Rankings row|w=y|r=4|t=AUS|p=1057|c=BCO}} {{IBAF World Rankings row|w=y|r=5|t=VEN|p=933|c=COPABE}} {{IBAF World Rankings row|w=y|r=6|t=TPE|p=907|c=BFA}} {{IBAF World Rankings row|w=y|r=7|t=KOR|p=430|c=BFA}} {{IBAF World Rankings row|w=y|r=8|t=NED|p=403|c=CEB}} {{IBAF World Rankings row|w=y|r=9|t=CUB|p=353|c=COPABE}} {{IBAF World Rankings row|w=y|r=10|t=HKG|p=343|c=BFA}} {{IBAF World Rankings row|w=y|r=11|t=IND|p=160|c=BFA}} {{IBAF World Rankings row|w=y|r=12|t=PAK|p=100|c=BFA}} |} The initial women's baseball rankings were based upon results from past [[Women's Baseball World Cup]]s. While the calculations of the women's rankings are similar to that of the men's, one main difference is that they are inclusive of the three most recent IBAF Women's Baseball World Cups whereas the men's rankings only include the last two. Points are weighted in favor of the more recent results.<ref name="ibaf women's rankings">{{cite web | url=http://www.ibaf.org/index.php?id=10&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=311&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=9&cHash=e4d61fbf48 | title=IBAF Releases First-Ever Women’s World Rankings | date=13 August 2009 | accessdate=13 August 2009 | publisher=International Baseball Federation | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5sBX8m4lp?url=http://www.ibaf.org/en/article-detail.aspx?id=7cdb8cdb-525d-4501-8f40-2d59622392e6 | archivedate=23 August 2010 | dead-url=no | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Softball rankings== In the wake of the [[International Olympic Committee]]'s decision to cut baseball from the [[2012 Olympics]] program, the IBAF pushed the growth of women's baseball as to include a women's component in its bid for a reinstatement of the sport in future Olympics. The effort to unify the sports resulted in the merger of the IBAF with the [[International Softball Federation]] in 2013 to create the WBSC.<ref>{{cite web|title=ABOUT THE WORLD BASEBALL SOFTBALL CONFEDERATION|url=http://wbsc.org/en/about|publisher=[[World Baseball Softball Confederation]]|accessdate=6 November 2015}}</ref> As a result, the WBSC is also responsible for ranking international men's and women's softball teams.<ref name="sb2016">{{cite news|title=WBSC launches first-ever Softball World Rankings: Japan Women’s No. 1, New Zealand Men’s No. 1|url=http://www.mister-baseball.com/wbsc-launches-firstever-softball-world-rankings-japan-womens-1-zealand-mens-1/|accessdate=29 March 2016|work=Mister Baseball|date=March 22, 2016}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%; float: left; margin-left: 1em" |- |colspan="3" style="text-align:center"|'''Women's Softball Rankings as of 19 December 2017'''<ref name="world rankings"/> |- !Rank!!Team!!Points |- ! 1 | {{sbw|USA}} || style="text-align:right"|4054 |- ! 2 | {{sbw|JPN}} || style="text-align:right"|3799 |- ! 3 | {{sbw|CAN}} || style="text-align:right"|3253 |- ! 4 | {{sbw|AUS}} || style="text-align:right"|2799 |- ! 5 | {{sbw|TPE}} || style="text-align:right"|2724 |- ! 6 | {{sbw|PUR}} || style="text-align:right"|2453 |- ! 7 | {{sbw|MEX}} || style="text-align:right"|2183 |- ! 8 | {{sbw|NED}} || style="text-align:right"|2133 |- ! 9 | {{sbw|ITA}} || style="text-align:right"|2100 |- ! 10 | {{sbw|CZE}} || style="text-align:right"|1970 |- ! 11 | {{sbw|NZL}} || style="text-align:right"|1953 |- ! 12 | {{sbw|CHN}} || style="text-align:right"|1867 |}

== Calculation method == {{Update|section|inaccurate=yes|date=March 2016}} Under the current system used, points are awarded to member nations based purely on their final position in recognised international tournaments.{{IBAF World Rankings ref/Notes}} This is opposed to other international sports ranking systems such as the [[ICC Test Championship]] for [[cricket]], that is based on both individual matches and the results of series, or the [[FIFA World Rankings]] for [[association football|football]], that is based solely on individual matches.
Points are awarded according to the following table: {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%; text-align:center;" |- ! Final position !! Points awarded |- | 1st || '''50''' |- | 2nd || '''40''' |- | 3rd || '''30''' |- | 4th || '''15''' |- | 5th – 2nd-last{{ref| *|*}} || Spread evenly between '''15''' & '''1''' |- | Last{{ref| *|*}} || '''1''' |} {{refbegin}} ''{{note|*|*}}'' - If more than 32 teams compete, points are only awarded to the first 32 teams. (i.e. the spread is from 5th - 31st, Last gets 1 point.) {{refend}}
The points awarded after 4th place are spread evenly in an attempt to ensure balance between tournaments with different-sized fields: finishing 6th out of 20 teams is considered to be a higher accomplishment than finishing 6th out of 8 teams. Given that points are not fixed beyond 4th place, a calculation is used to determine how many points are awarded to each position. The calculation gives the difference between any two consecutive positions from 4th through to last (e.g. 4th and 5th, 7th and 8th, 21st and 22nd, etc.). The calculation is:
:<math>Points\ difference\ = \frac{14}{No\ of\ teams\ -\ 4}</math>
This is illustrated in the following table: {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 90%; text-align:center;" |- ! Number of teams !! Points difference !! 4th !! 5th !! 2nd-Last !! Last |- | 6 || 7 || rowspan=5 | 15 || colspan=2 | 8 || rowspan=5 | 1 |- | 8 || 3 <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> || 11 <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> || 4 <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> |- | 12 || 1 <sup>3</sup>/<sub>4</sub> || 13 <sup>1</sup>/<sub>4</sub> || 2 <sup>3</sup>/<sub>4</sub> |- | 16 || 1 <sup>1</sup>/<sub>6</sub> || 13 <sup>5</sup>/<sub>6</sub> || 2 <sup>1</sup>/<sub>6</sub> |- | 32 || <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> || 14 <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> || 1 <sup>1</sup>/<sub>2</sub> |} A multiplier is used in awarding points, based on the prestige of the tournament and the quality of the teams involved. The table below reflects the changes in the international baseball schedule recently approved by the WBSC. Below are the multipliers that will be used beginning in 2012.
[[World Baseball Classic]] 6x (Winner receives 50 points, multiplied by 6 for a total of 300 points)
Premier 12 6x
WBC Qualifiers * (Pool winner receives 50 points, 2nd – 40 pts, 3rd – 30 pts, 4th – 15 pts)
21U and 18U 2x
15U and 12U 1x
Continental Championships, Continental Qualifiers, and all other WBSC-sponsored events will receive a multiplier based on the number of top-10 teams from the previous year-end rankings that are entered in the tournament. (See below)
1.00× - Continental Championships/Qualifying Tournaments, where 3 or more competing teams are in the previous year-end top 10
0.75× - Continental Championships/Qualifying Tournaments, where 2 competing teams are in the previous year-end top 10
0.50× - Continental Championships/Qualifying Tournaments, where 1 competing team is in the previous year-end top 10
0.25× - Continental Championships/Qualifying Tournaments, where no competing teams are in the previous year-end top 10
After each tournament where ranking points are awarded, the WBSC re-releases the ranking list with the points from the most recent tournament added, and points from tournaments more than four years old removed.
